# Introduction[](#introduction) ## What is Markdown?[](#what-is-markdown) Markdown is a plain text format for writing structured documents, based on conventions for indicating formatting in email and usenet posts. It was developed by John Gruber (with help from Aaron Swartz) and released in 2004 in the form of a [syntax description](http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax) and a Perl script (`Markdown.pl`) for converting Markdown to HTML. In the next decade, dozens of implementations were developed in many languages. Some extended the original Markdown syntax with conventions for footnotes, tables, and other document elements. Some allowed Markdown documents to be rendered in formats other than HTML. Websites like Reddit, StackOverflow, and GitHub had millions of people using Markdown. And Markdown started to be used beyond the web, to author books, articles, slide shows, letters, and lecture notes. What distinguishes Markdown from many other lightweight markup syntaxes, which are often easier to write, is its readability. As Gruber writes: > The overriding design goal for Markdown's formatting syntax is to make it as readable as possible. The idea is that a Markdown-formatted document should be publishable as-is, as plain text, without looking like it's been marked up with tags or formatting instructions. () The point can be illustrated by comparing a sample of [AsciiDoc](http://www.methods.co.nz/asciidoc/) with an equivalent sample of Markdown. Here is a sample of AsciiDoc from the AsciiDoc manual: 1. List item one. + List item one continued with a second paragraph followed by an Indented block. + ................. $ ls *.sh $ mv *.sh ~/tmp ................. + List item continued with a third paragraph. 2. List item two continued with an open block. + -- This paragraph is part of the preceding list item. a. This list is nested and does not require explicit item continuation. + This paragraph is part of the preceding list item. b. List item b. This paragraph belongs to item two of the outer list. -- And here is the equivalent in Markdown: 1. List item one. List item one continued with a second paragraph followed by an Indented block. $ ls *.sh $ mv *.sh ~/tmp List item continued with a third paragraph. 2. List item two continued with an open block. This paragraph is part of the preceding list item. 1. This list is nested and does not require explicit item continuation. This paragraph is part of the preceding list item. 2. List item b. This paragraph belongs to item two of the outer list. The AsciiDoc version is, arguably, easier to write. You don't need to worry about indentation. But the Markdown version is much easier to read. The nesting of list items is apparent to the eye in the source, not just in the processed document. ## Why is a spec needed?[](#why-is-a-spec-needed) John Gruber's [canonical description of Markdown's syntax](http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax) does not specify the syntax unambiguously. Here are some examples of questions it does not answer: 1. How much indentation is needed for a sublist? The spec says that continuation paragraphs need to be indented four spaces, but is not fully explicit about sublists. It is natural to think that they, too, must be indented four spaces, but `Markdown.pl` does not require that. This is hardly a "corner case," and divergences between implementations on this issue often lead to surprises for users in real documents. (See [this comment by John Gruber](https://web.archive.org/web/20170611172104/http://article.gmane.org/gmane.text.markdown.general/1997).) 2. Is a blank line needed before a block quote or heading? Most implementations do not require the blank line. However, this can lead to unexpected results in hard-wrapped text, and also to ambiguities in parsing (note that some implementations put the heading inside the blockquote, while others do not). (John Gruber has also spoken [in favor of requiring the blank lines](https://web.archive.org/web/20170611172104/http://article.gmane.org/gmane.text.markdown.general/2146).) 3. Is a blank line needed before an indented code block? (`Markdown.pl` requires it, but this is not mentioned in the documentation, and some implementations do not require it.) ```markdown paragraph code? ``` 4. What is the exact rule for determining when list items get wrapped in `

` tags? Can a list be partially "loose" and partially "tight"? What should we do with a list like this? ```markdown 1. one 2. two 3. three ``` Or this? ```markdown 1. one - a - b 2. two ``` (There are some relevant comments by John Gruber [here](https://web.archive.org/web/20170611172104/http://article.gmane.org/gmane.text.markdown.general/2554).) 5. Can list markers be indented? Can ordered list markers be right-aligned? ```markdown 8. item 1 9. item 2 10. item 2a ``` 6. Is this one list with a thematic break in its second item, or two lists separated by a thematic break? ```markdown * a * * * * * * b ``` 7. When list markers change from numbers to bullets, do we have two lists or one? (The Markdown syntax description suggests two, but the perl scripts and many other implementations produce one.) ```markdown 1. fee 2. fie - foe - fum ``` 8. What are the precedence rules for the markers of inline structure? For example, is the following a valid link, or does the code span take precedence ? ```markdown [a backtick (`)](/url) and [another backtick (`)](/url). ``` 9. What are the precedence rules for markers of emphasis and strong emphasis? For example, how should the following be parsed? ```markdown *foo *bar* baz* ``` 10. What are the precedence rules between block-level and inline-level structure? For example, how should the following be parsed? ```markdown - `a long code span can contain a hyphen like this - and it can screw things up` ``` 11. Can list items include section headings? (`Markdown.pl` does not allow this, but does allow blockquotes to include headings.) ```markdown - # Heading ``` 12. Can list items be empty? ```markdown * a * * b ``` 13. Can link references be defined inside block quotes or list items? ```markdown > Blockquote [foo]. > > [foo]: /url ``` 14. If there are multiple definitions for the same reference, which takes precedence? ```markdown [foo]: /url1 [foo]: /url2 [foo][] ``` In the absence of a spec, early implementers consulted `Markdown.pl` to resolve these ambiguities. But `Markdown.pl` was quite buggy, and gave manifestly bad results in many cases, so it was not a satisfactory replacement for a spec. Because there is no unambiguous spec, implementations have diverged considerably. As a result, users are often surprised to find that a document that renders one way on one system (say, a GitHub wiki) renders differently on another (say, converting to docbook using pandoc). To make matters worse, because nothing in Markdown counts as a "syntax error," the divergence often isn't discovered right away. ## About this document[](#about-this-document) This document attempts to specify Markdown syntax unambiguously. It contains many examples with side-by-side Markdown and HTML. These are intended to double as conformance tests. An accompanying script `spec_tests.py` can be used to run the tests against any Markdown program: python test/spec_tests.py --spec spec.txt --program PROGRAM Since this document describes how Markdown is to be parsed into an abstract syntax tree, it would have made sense to use an abstract representation of the syntax tree instead of HTML. But HTML is capable of representing the structural distinctions we need to make, and the choice of HTML for the tests makes it possible to run the tests against an implementation without writing an abstract syntax tree renderer. Note that not every feature of the HTML samples is mandated by the spec. For example, the spec says what counts as a link destination, but it doesn't mandate that non-ASCII characters in the URL be percent-encoded. To use the automatic tests, implementers will need to provide a renderer that conforms to the expectations of the spec examples (percent-encoding non-ASCII characters in URLs). But a conforming implementation can use a different renderer and may choose not to percent-encode non-ASCII characters in URLs. This document is generated from a text file, `spec.txt`, written in Markdown with a small extension for the side-by-side tests. The script `tools/makespec.py` can be used to convert `spec.txt` into HTML or CommonMark (which can then be converted into other formats). In the examples, the `→` character is used to represent tabs. # Preliminaries[](#preliminaries) ## Characters and lines[](#characters-and-lines) Any sequence of [characters](#character) is a valid CommonMark document. A [character](#character) is a Unicode code point. Although some code points (for example, combining accents) do not correspond to characters in an intuitive sense, all code points count as characters for purposes of this spec. This spec does not specify an encoding; it thinks of lines as composed of [characters](#character) rather than bytes. A conforming parser may be limited to a certain encoding. A [line](#line) is a sequence of zero or more [characters](#character) other than line feed (`U+000A`) or carriage return (`U+000D`), followed by a [line ending](#line-ending) or by the end of file. A [line ending](#line-ending) is a line feed (`U+000A`), a carriage return (`U+000D`) not followed by a line feed, or a carriage return and a following line feed. A line containing no characters, or a line containing only spaces (`U+0020`) or tabs (`U+0009`), is called a [blank line](#blank-line). The following definitions of character classes will be used in this spec: A [Unicode whitespace character](#unicode-whitespace-character) is any code point in the Unicode `Zs` general category, or a tab (`U+0009`), line feed (`U+000A`), form feed (`U+000C`), or carriage return (`U+000D`). [Unicode whitespace](#unicode-whitespace) is a sequence of one or more [Unicode whitespace characters](#unicode-whitespace-character). A [tab](#tab) is `U+0009`. A [space](#space) is `U+0020`. An [ASCII control character](#ascii-control-character) is a character between `U+0000–1F` (both including) or `U+007F`. An [ASCII punctuation character](#ascii-punctuation-character) is `!`, `"`, `#`, `$`, `%`, `&`, `'`, `(`, `)`, `*`, `+`, `,`, `-`, `.`, `/` (U+0021–2F), `:`, `;`, `<`, `=`, `>`, `?`, `@` (U+003A–0040), `[`, `\`, `]`, `^`, `_`, `` ` `` (U+005B–0060), `{`, `|`, `}`, or `~` (U+007B–007E). A [Unicode punctuation character](#unicode-punctuation-character) is an [ASCII punctuation character](#ascii-punctuation-character) or anything in the general Unicode categories `Pc`, `Pd`, `Pe`, `Pf`, `Pi`, `Po`, or `Ps`. ## Tabs[](#tabs) Tabs in lines are not expanded to [spaces](#space). However, in contexts where spaces help to define block structure, tabs behave as if they were replaced by spaces with a tab stop of 4 characters. Thus, for example, a tab can be used instead of four spaces in an indented code block. (Note, however, that internal tabs are passed through as literal tabs, not expanded to spaces.) [Example 1](#example-1)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%09foo%09baz%09%09bim "open in interactive dingus") ```example →foo→baz→→bim ``` 

foo→baz→→bim
[Example 2](#example-2)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%09foo%09baz%09%09bim "open in interactive dingus") ```example →foo→baz→→bim ``` 
foo→baz→→bim
[Example 3](#example-3)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%20%20a%09a%0A%20%20%20%20%E1%BD%90%09a "open in interactive dingus") ```example a→a ὐ→a ``` 
a→a
    ὐ→a
In the following example, a continuation paragraph of a list item is indented with a tab; this has exactly the same effect as indentation with four spaces would: [Example 4](#example-4)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20-%20foo%0A%0A%09bar "open in interactive dingus") ```example - foo →bar ```

  • foo

    bar

[Example 5](#example-5)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=-%20foo%0A%0A%09%09bar "open in interactive dingus") ```example - foo →→bar ```

  • foo

      bar
Normally the `>` that begins a block quote may be followed optionally by a space, which is not considered part of the content. In the following case `>` is followed by a tab, which is treated as if it were expanded into three spaces. Since one of these spaces is considered part of the delimiter, `foo` is considered to be indented six spaces inside the block quote context, so we get an indented code block starting with two spaces. [Example 6](#example-6)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%09%09foo "open in interactive dingus") ```example >→→foo ``` 
  foo
[Example 7](#example-7)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=-%09%09foo "open in interactive dingus") ```example -→→foo ``` 
  •   foo
[Example 8](#example-8)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%20%20foo%0A%09bar "open in interactive dingus") ```example foo →bar ``` 
foo
    bar
[Example 9](#example-9)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20-%20foo%0A%20%20%20-%20bar%0A%09%20-%20baz "open in interactive dingus") ```example - foo - bar → - baz ```
  • foo
    • bar
      • baz
[Example 10](#example-10)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%23%09Foo "open in interactive dingus") ```example #→Foo ```

Foo

[Example 11](#example-11)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=*%09*%09*%09 "open in interactive dingus") ```example *→*→*→ ```
## Insecure characters[](#insecure-characters) For security reasons, the Unicode character `U+0000` must be replaced with the REPLACEMENT CHARACTER (`U+FFFD`). ## Backslash escapes[](#backslash-escapes) Any ASCII punctuation character may be backslash-escaped: [Example 12](#example-12)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5C!%5C%22%5C%23%5C%24%5C%25%5C%26%5C'%5C\(%5C\)%5C*%5C%2B%5C%2C%5C-%5C.%5C%2F%5C%3A%5C%3B%5C%3C%5C%3D%5C%3E%5C%3F%5C%40%5C%5B%5C%5C%5C%5D%5C%5E%5C_%5C%60%5C%7B%5C%7C%5C%7D%5C~ "open in interactive dingus") ```example \!\"\#\$\%\&\'\(\)\*\+\,\-\.\/\:\;\<\=\>\?\@\[\\\]\^\_\`\{\|\}\~ ```

!"#$%&'()*+,-./:;<=>?@[\]^_`{|}~

Backslashes before other characters are treated as literal backslashes: [Example 13](#example-13)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5C%09%5CA%5Ca%5C%20%5C3%5C%CF%86%5C%C2%AB "open in interactive dingus") ```example \→\A\a\ \3\φ\« ```

\→\A\a\ \3\φ\«

Escaped characters are treated as regular characters and do not have their usual Markdown meanings: [Example 14](#example-14)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5C*not%20emphasized*%0A%5C%3Cbr%2F%3E%20not%20a%20tag%0A%5C%5Bnot%20a%20link%5D\(%2Ffoo\)%0A%5C%60not%20code%60%0A1%5C.%20not%20a%20list%0A%5C*%20not%20a%20list%0A%5C%23%20not%20a%20heading%0A%5C%5Bfoo%5D%3A%20%2Furl%20%22not%20a%20reference%22%0A%5C%26ouml%3B%20not%20a%20character%20entity "open in interactive dingus") ```example \*not emphasized* \
not a tag \[not a link](/foo) \`not code` 1\. not a list \* not a list \# not a heading \[foo]: /url "not a reference" \ö not a character entity ```

*not emphasized* <br/> not a tag [not a link](/foo) `not code` 1. not a list * not a list # not a heading [foo]: /url "not a reference" ö not a character entity

If a backslash is itself escaped, the following character is not: [Example 15](#example-15)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5C%5C*emphasis* "open in interactive dingus") ```example \\*emphasis* ```

\emphasis

A backslash at the end of the line is a [hard line break](#hard-line-break): [Example 16](#example-16)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=foo%5C%0Abar "open in interactive dingus") ```example foo\ bar ```

foo
bar

Backslash escapes do not work in code blocks, code spans, autolinks, or raw HTML: [Example 17](#example-17)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%60%60%20%5C%5B%5C%60%20%60%60 "open in interactive dingus") ```example `` \[\` `` ```

\[\`

[Example 18](#example-18)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%20%20%5C%5B%5C%5D "open in interactive dingus") ```example \[\] ``` 
\[\]
[Example 19](#example-19)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=~~~%0A%5C%5B%5C%5D%0A~~~ "open in interactive dingus") ```example ~~~ \[\] ~~~ ``` 
\[\]
[Example 20](#example-20)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3Chttp%3A%2F%2Fexample.com%3Ffind%3D%5C*%3E "open in interactive dingus") ```example ```

http://example.com?find=\*

[Example 21](#example-21)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3Ca%20href%3D%22%2Fbar%5C%2F\)%22%3E "open in interactive dingus") ```example ``` But they work in all other contexts, including URLs and link titles, link references, and [info strings](#info-string) in [fenced code blocks](#fenced-code-block): [Example 22](#example-22)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5Bfoo%5D\(%2Fbar%5C*%20%22ti%5C*tle%22\) "open in interactive dingus") ```example [foo](/bar\* "ti\*tle") ```

foo

[Example 23](#example-23)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5Bfoo%5D%0A%0A%5Bfoo%5D%3A%20%2Fbar%5C*%20%22ti%5C*tle%22 "open in interactive dingus") ```example [foo] [foo]: /bar\* "ti\*tle" ```

foo

[Example 24](#example-24)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%60%60%60%20foo%5C%2Bbar%0Afoo%0A%60%60%60 "open in interactive dingus") ````example ``` foo\+bar foo ``` ```` 
foo
## Entity and numeric character references[](#entity-and-numeric-character-references) Valid HTML entity references and numeric character references can be used in place of the corresponding Unicode character, with the following exceptions: * Entity and character references are not recognized in code blocks and code spans. * Entity and character references cannot stand in place of special characters that define structural elements in CommonMark. For example, although `*` can be used in place of a literal `*` character, `*` cannot replace `*` in emphasis delimiters, bullet list markers, or thematic breaks. Conforming CommonMark parsers need not store information about whether a particular character was represented in the source using a Unicode character or an entity reference. [Entity references](#entity-references) consist of `&` + any of the valid HTML5 entity names + `;`. The document is used as an authoritative source for the valid entity references and their corresponding code points. [Example 25](#example-25)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%26nbsp%3B%20%26amp%3B%20%26copy%3B%20%26AElig%3B%20%26Dcaron%3B%0A%26frac34%3B%20%26HilbertSpace%3B%20%26DifferentialD%3B%0A%26ClockwiseContourIntegral%3B%20%26ngE%3B "open in interactive dingus") ```example   & © Æ Ď ¾ ℋ ⅆ ∲ ≧̸ ```

  & © Æ Ď ¾ ℋ ⅆ ∲ ≧̸

[Decimal numeric character references](#decimal-numeric-character-references) consist of `&#` + a string of 1--7 arabic digits + `;`. A numeric character reference is parsed as the corresponding Unicode character. Invalid Unicode code points will be replaced by the REPLACEMENT CHARACTER (`U+FFFD`). For security reasons, the code point `U+0000` will also be replaced by `U+FFFD`. [Example 26](#example-26)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%26%2335%3B%20%26%231234%3B%20%26%23992%3B%20%26%230%3B "open in interactive dingus") ```example # Ӓ Ϡ � ```

# Ӓ Ϡ �

[Hexadecimal numeric character references](#hexadecimal-numeric-character-references) consist of `&#` + either `X` or `x` + a string of 1-6 hexadecimal digits + `;`. They too are parsed as the corresponding Unicode character (this time specified with a hexadecimal numeral instead of decimal). [Example 27](#example-27)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%26%23X22%3B%20%26%23XD06%3B%20%26%23xcab%3B "open in interactive dingus") ```example " ആ ಫ ```

" ആ ಫ

Here are some nonentities: [Example 28](#example-28)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%26nbsp%20%26x%3B%20%26%23%3B%20%26%23x%3B%0A%26%2387654321%3B%0A%26%23abcdef0%3B%0A%26ThisIsNotDefined%3B%20%26hi%3F%3B "open in interactive dingus") ```example   &x; &#; &#x; � &#abcdef0; &ThisIsNotDefined; &hi?; ```

&nbsp &x; &#; &#x; &#87654321; &#abcdef0; &ThisIsNotDefined; &hi?;

Although HTML5 does accept some entity references without a trailing semicolon (such as `©`), these are not recognized here, because it makes the grammar too ambiguous: [Example 29](#example-29)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%26copy "open in interactive dingus") ```example © ```

&copy

Strings that are not on the list of HTML5 named entities are not recognized as entity references either: [Example 30](#example-30)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%26MadeUpEntity%3B "open in interactive dingus") ```example &MadeUpEntity; ```

&MadeUpEntity;

Entity and numeric character references are recognized in any context besides code spans or code blocks, including URLs, [link titles](#link-title), and \[fenced code block]\[] [info strings](#info-string): [Example 31](#example-31)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3Ca%20href%3D%22%26ouml%3B%26ouml%3B.html%22%3E "open in interactive dingus") ```example ``` [Example 32](#example-32)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5Bfoo%5D\(%2Ff%26ouml%3B%26ouml%3B%20%22f%26ouml%3B%26ouml%3B%22\) "open in interactive dingus") ```example [foo](/föö "föö") ```

foo

[Example 33](#example-33)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5Bfoo%5D%0A%0A%5Bfoo%5D%3A%20%2Ff%26ouml%3B%26ouml%3B%20%22f%26ouml%3B%26ouml%3B%22 "open in interactive dingus") ```example [foo] [foo]: /föö "föö" ```

foo

[Example 34](#example-34)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%60%60%60%20f%26ouml%3B%26ouml%3B%0Afoo%0A%60%60%60 "open in interactive dingus") ````example ``` föö foo ``` ```` 
foo
Entity and numeric character references are treated as literal text in code spans and code blocks: [Example 35](#example-35)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%60f%26ouml%3B%26ouml%3B%60 "open in interactive dingus") ```example `föö` ```

föö

[Example 36](#example-36)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%20%20f%26ouml%3Bf%26ouml%3B "open in interactive dingus") ```example föfö ``` 
föfö
Entity and numeric character references cannot be used in place of symbols indicating structure in CommonMark documents. [Example 37](#example-37)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%26%2342%3Bfoo%26%2342%3B%0A*foo* "open in interactive dingus") ```example *foo* *foo* ```

*foo* foo

[Example 38](#example-38)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%26%2342%3B%20foo%0A%0A*%20foo "open in interactive dingus") ```example * foo * foo ```

* foo

  • foo
[Example 39](#example-39)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=foo%26%2310%3B%26%2310%3Bbar "open in interactive dingus") ```example foo bar ```

foo bar

[Example 40](#example-40)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%26%239%3Bfoo "open in interactive dingus") ```example foo ```

→foo

[Example 41](#example-41)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5Ba%5D\(url%20%26quot%3Btit%26quot%3B\) "open in interactive dingus") ```example [a](url "tit") ```

[a](url "tit")

# Blocks and inlines[](#blocks-and-inlines) We can think of a document as a sequence of [blocks](#blocks)---structural elements like paragraphs, block quotations, lists, headings, rules, and code blocks. Some blocks (like block quotes and list items) contain other blocks; others (like headings and paragraphs) contain [inline](#inline) content---text, links, emphasized text, images, code spans, and so on. ## Precedence[](#precedence) Indicators of block structure always take precedence over indicators of inline structure. So, for example, the following is a list with two items, not a list with one item containing a code span: [Example 42](#example-42)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=-%20%60one%0A-%20two%60 "open in interactive dingus") ```example - `one - two` ```
  • `one
  • two`
This means that parsing can proceed in two steps: first, the block structure of the document can be discerned; second, text lines inside paragraphs, headings, and other block constructs can be parsed for inline structure. The second step requires information about link reference definitions that will be available only at the end of the first step. Note that the first step requires processing lines in sequence, but the second can be parallelized, since the inline parsing of one block element does not affect the inline parsing of any other. ## Container blocks and leaf blocks[](#container-blocks-and-leaf-blocks) We can divide blocks into two types: [container blocks](#container-blocks), which can contain other blocks, and [leaf blocks](#leaf-blocks), which cannot. # Leaf blocks[](#leaf-blocks) This section describes the different kinds of leaf block that make up a Markdown document. ## Thematic breaks[](#thematic-breaks) A line consisting of optionally up to three spaces of indentation, followed by a sequence of three or more matching `-`, `_`, or `*` characters, each followed optionally by any number of spaces or tabs, forms a [thematic break](#thematic-break). [Example 43](#example-43)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=***%0A---%0A___ "open in interactive dingus") ```example *** --- ___ ```
Wrong characters: [Example 44](#example-44)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%2B%2B%2B "open in interactive dingus") ```example +++ ```

+++

[Example 45](#example-45)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3D%3D%3D "open in interactive dingus") ```example === ```

===

Not enough characters: [Example 46](#example-46)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=--%0A**%0A__ "open in interactive dingus") ```example -- ** __ ```

-- ** __

Up to three spaces of indentation are allowed: [Example 47](#example-47)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20***%0A%20%20***%0A%20%20%20*** "open in interactive dingus") ```example *** *** *** ```
Four spaces of indentation is too many: [Example 48](#example-48)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%20%20*** "open in interactive dingus") ```example *** ``` 
***
[Example 49](#example-49)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=Foo%0A%20%20%20%20*** "open in interactive dingus") ```example Foo *** ```

Foo ***

More than three characters may be used: [Example 50](#example-50)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=_____________________________________ "open in interactive dingus") ```example _____________________________________ ```
Spaces and tabs are allowed between the characters: [Example 51](#example-51)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20-%20-%20- "open in interactive dingus") ```example - - - ```
[Example 52](#example-52)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20**%20%20*%20**%20*%20**%20*%20** "open in interactive dingus") ```example ** * ** * ** * ** ```
[Example 53](#example-53)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=-%20%20%20%20%20-%20%20%20%20%20%20-%20%20%20%20%20%20- "open in interactive dingus") ```example - - - - ```
Spaces and tabs are allowed at the end: [Example 54](#example-54)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=-%20-%20-%20-%20%20%20%20 "open in interactive dingus") ```example - - - - ```
However, no other characters may occur in the line: [Example 55](#example-55)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=_%20_%20_%20_%20a%0A%0Aa------%0A%0A---a--- "open in interactive dingus") ```example _ _ _ _ a a------ ---a--- ```

_ _ _ _ a

a------

---a---

It is required that all of the characters other than spaces or tabs be the same. So, this is not a thematic break: [Example 56](#example-56)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20*-* "open in interactive dingus") ```example *-* ```

-

Thematic breaks do not need blank lines before or after: [Example 57](#example-57)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=-%20foo%0A***%0A-%20bar "open in interactive dingus") ```example - foo *** - bar ```
  • foo
  • bar
Thematic breaks can interrupt a paragraph: [Example 58](#example-58)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=Foo%0A***%0Abar "open in interactive dingus") ```example Foo *** bar ```

Foo

bar

If a line of dashes that meets the above conditions for being a thematic break could also be interpreted as the underline of a [setext heading](#setext-heading), the interpretation as a [setext heading](#setext-heading) takes precedence. Thus, for example, this is a setext heading, not a paragraph followed by a thematic break: [Example 59](#example-59)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=Foo%0A---%0Abar "open in interactive dingus") ```example Foo --- bar ```

Foo

bar

When both a thematic break and a list item are possible interpretations of a line, the thematic break takes precedence: [Example 60](#example-60)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=*%20Foo%0A*%20*%20*%0A*%20Bar "open in interactive dingus") ```example * Foo * * * * Bar ```
  • Foo
  • Bar
If you want a thematic break in a list item, use a different bullet: [Example 61](#example-61)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=-%20Foo%0A-%20*%20*%20* "open in interactive dingus") ```example - Foo - * * * ```
  • Foo
## ATX headings[](#atx-headings) An [ATX heading](#atx-heading) consists of a string of characters, parsed as inline content, between an opening sequence of 1--6 unescaped `#` characters and an optional closing sequence of any number of unescaped `#` characters. The opening sequence of `#` characters must be followed by spaces or tabs, or by the end of line. The optional closing sequence of `#`s must be preceded by spaces or tabs and may be followed by spaces or tabs only. The opening `#` character may be preceded by up to three spaces of indentation. The raw contents of the heading are stripped of leading and trailing space or tabs before being parsed as inline content. The heading level is equal to the number of `#` characters in the opening sequence. Simple headings: [Example 62](#example-62)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%23%20foo%0A%23%23%20foo%0A%23%23%23%20foo%0A%23%23%23%23%20foo%0A%23%23%23%23%23%20foo%0A%23%23%23%23%23%23%20foo "open in interactive dingus") ```example # foo ## foo ### foo #### foo ##### foo ###### foo ```

foo

foo

foo

foo

foo
foo
More than six `#` characters is not a heading: [Example 63](#example-63)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%20foo "open in interactive dingus") ```example ####### foo ```

####### foo

At least one space or tab is required between the `#` characters and the heading's contents, unless the heading is empty. Note that many implementations currently do not require the space. However, the space was required by the [original ATX implementation](http://www.aaronsw.com/2002/atx/atx.py), and it helps prevent things like the following from being parsed as headings: [Example 64](#example-64)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%235%20bolt%0A%0A%23hashtag "open in interactive dingus") ```example #5 bolt #hashtag ```

#5 bolt

#hashtag

This is not a heading, because the first `#` is escaped: [Example 65](#example-65)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5C%23%23%20foo "open in interactive dingus") ```example \## foo ```

## foo

Contents are parsed as inlines: [Example 66](#example-66)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%23%20foo%20*bar*%20%5C*baz%5C* "open in interactive dingus") ```example # foo *bar* \*baz\* ```

foo bar *baz*

Leading and trailing spaces or tabs are ignored in parsing inline content: [Example 67](#example-67)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%23%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20foo%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20 "open in interactive dingus") ```example # foo ```

foo

Up to three spaces of indentation are allowed: [Example 68](#example-68)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%23%23%23%20foo%0A%20%20%23%23%20foo%0A%20%20%20%23%20foo "open in interactive dingus") ```example ### foo ## foo # foo ```

foo

foo

foo

Four spaces of indentation is too many: [Example 69](#example-69)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%20%20%23%20foo "open in interactive dingus") ```example # foo ``` 
# foo
[Example 70](#example-70)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=foo%0A%20%20%20%20%23%20bar "open in interactive dingus") ```example foo # bar ```

foo # bar

A closing sequence of `#` characters is optional: [Example 71](#example-71)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%23%23%20foo%20%23%23%0A%20%20%23%23%23%20%20%20bar%20%20%20%20%23%23%23 "open in interactive dingus") ```example ## foo ## ### bar ### ```

foo

bar

It need not be the same length as the opening sequence: [Example 72](#example-72)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%23%20foo%20%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%23%0A%23%23%23%23%23%20foo%20%23%23 "open in interactive dingus") ```example # foo ################################## ##### foo ## ```

foo

foo
Spaces or tabs are allowed after the closing sequence: [Example 73](#example-73)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%23%23%23%20foo%20%23%23%23%20%20%20%20%20 "open in interactive dingus") ```example ### foo ### ```

foo

A sequence of `#` characters with anything but spaces or tabs following it is not a closing sequence, but counts as part of the contents of the heading: [Example 74](#example-74)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%23%23%23%20foo%20%23%23%23%20b "open in interactive dingus") ```example ### foo ### b ```

foo ### b

The closing sequence must be preceded by a space or tab: [Example 75](#example-75)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%23%20foo%23 "open in interactive dingus") ```example # foo# ```

foo#

Backslash-escaped `#` characters do not count as part of the closing sequence: [Example 76](#example-76)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%23%23%23%20foo%20%5C%23%23%23%0A%23%23%20foo%20%23%5C%23%23%0A%23%20foo%20%5C%23 "open in interactive dingus") ```example ### foo \### ## foo #\## # foo \# ```

foo ###

foo ###

foo #

ATX headings need not be separated from surrounding content by blank lines, and they can interrupt paragraphs: [Example 77](#example-77)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=****%0A%23%23%20foo%0A**** "open in interactive dingus") ```example **** ## foo **** ```

foo

[Example 78](#example-78)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=Foo%20bar%0A%23%20baz%0ABar%20foo "open in interactive dingus") ```example Foo bar # baz Bar foo ```

Foo bar

baz

Bar foo

ATX headings can be empty: [Example 79](#example-79)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%23%23%20%0A%23%0A%23%23%23%20%23%23%23 "open in interactive dingus") ```example ## # ### ### ```

## Setext headings[](#setext-headings) A [setext heading](#setext-heading) consists of one or more lines of text, not interrupted by a blank line, of which the first line does not have more than 3 spaces of indentation, followed by a [setext heading underline](#setext-heading-underline). The lines of text must be such that, were they not followed by the setext heading underline, they would be interpreted as a paragraph: they cannot be interpretable as a [code fence](#code-fence), [ATX heading](#atx-heading), [block quote](#block-quotes), [thematic break](#thematic-break), [list item](#list-items), or [HTML block](#html-block). A [setext heading underline](#setext-heading-underline) is a sequence of `=` characters or a sequence of `-` characters, with no more than 3 spaces of indentation and any number of trailing spaces or tabs. The heading is a level 1 heading if `=` characters are used in the [setext heading underline](#setext-heading-underline), and a level 2 heading if `-` characters are used. The contents of the heading are the result of parsing the preceding lines of text as CommonMark inline content. In general, a setext heading need not be preceded or followed by a blank line. However, it cannot interrupt a paragraph, so when a setext heading comes after a paragraph, a blank line is needed between them. Simple examples: [Example 80](#example-80)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=Foo%20*bar*%0A%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%3D%0A%0AFoo%20*bar*%0A--------- "open in interactive dingus") ```example Foo *bar* ========= Foo *bar* --------- ```

Foo bar

Foo bar

The content of the header may span more than one line: [Example 81](#example-81)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=Foo%20*bar%0Abaz*%0A%3D%3D%3D%3D "open in interactive dingus") ```example Foo *bar baz* ==== ```

Foo bar baz

The contents are the result of parsing the headings's raw content as inlines. The heading's raw content is formed by concatenating the lines and removing initial and final spaces or tabs. [Example 82](#example-82)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20Foo%20*bar%0Abaz*%09%0A%3D%3D%3D%3D "open in interactive dingus") ```example Foo *bar baz*→ ==== ```

Foo bar baz

The underlining can be any length: [Example 83](#example-83)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=Foo%0A-------------------------%0A%0AFoo%0A%3D "open in interactive dingus") ```example Foo ------------------------- Foo = ```

Foo

Foo

The heading content can be preceded by up to three spaces of indentation, and need not line up with the underlining: [Example 84](#example-84)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%20Foo%0A---%0A%0A%20%20Foo%0A-----%0A%0A%20%20Foo%0A%20%20%3D%3D%3D "open in interactive dingus") ```example Foo --- Foo ----- Foo === ```

Foo

Foo

Foo

Four spaces of indentation is too many: [Example 85](#example-85)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%20%20Foo%0A%20%20%20%20---%0A%0A%20%20%20%20Foo%0A--- "open in interactive dingus") ```example Foo --- Foo --- ``` 
Foo
    ---

    Foo
The setext heading underline can be preceded by up to three spaces of indentation, and may have trailing spaces or tabs: [Example 86](#example-86)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=Foo%0A%20%20%20----%20%20%20%20%20%20 "open in interactive dingus") ```example Foo ---- ```

Foo

Four spaces of indentation is too many: [Example 87](#example-87)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=Foo%0A%20%20%20%20--- "open in interactive dingus") ```example Foo --- ```

Foo ---

The setext heading underline cannot contain internal spaces or tabs: [Example 88](#example-88)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=Foo%0A%3D%20%3D%0A%0AFoo%0A---%20- "open in interactive dingus") ```example Foo = = Foo --- - ```

Foo = =

Foo

Trailing spaces or tabs in the content line do not cause a hard line break: [Example 89](#example-89)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=Foo%20%20%0A----- "open in interactive dingus") ```example Foo ----- ```

Foo

Nor does a backslash at the end: [Example 90](#example-90)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=Foo%5C%0A---- "open in interactive dingus") ```example Foo\ ---- ```

Foo\

Since indicators of block structure take precedence over indicators of inline structure, the following are setext headings: [Example 91](#example-91)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%60Foo%0A----%0A%60%0A%0A%3Ca%20title%3D%22a%20lot%0A---%0Aof%20dashes%22%2F%3E "open in interactive dingus") ```example `Foo ---- ` ```

`Foo

`

<a title="a lot

of dashes"/>

The setext heading underline cannot be a [lazy continuation line](#lazy-continuation-line) in a list item or block quote: [Example 92](#example-92)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%20Foo%0A--- "open in interactive dingus") ```example > Foo --- ```

Foo

[Example 93](#example-93)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%20foo%0Abar%0A%3D%3D%3D "open in interactive dingus") ```example > foo bar === ```

foo bar ===

[Example 94](#example-94)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=-%20Foo%0A--- "open in interactive dingus") ```example - Foo --- ```
  • Foo
A blank line is needed between a paragraph and a following setext heading, since otherwise the paragraph becomes part of the heading's content: [Example 95](#example-95)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=Foo%0ABar%0A--- "open in interactive dingus") ```example Foo Bar --- ```

Foo Bar

But in general a blank line is not required before or after setext headings: [Example 96](#example-96)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=---%0AFoo%0A---%0ABar%0A---%0ABaz "open in interactive dingus") ```example --- Foo --- Bar --- Baz ```

Foo

Bar

Baz

Setext headings cannot be empty: [Example 97](#example-97)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%0A%3D%3D%3D%3D "open in interactive dingus") ```example ==== ```

====

Setext heading text lines must not be interpretable as block constructs other than paragraphs. So, the line of dashes in these examples gets interpreted as a thematic break: [Example 98](#example-98)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=---%0A--- "open in interactive dingus") ```example --- --- ```
[Example 99](#example-99)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=-%20foo%0A----- "open in interactive dingus") ```example - foo ----- ```
  • foo
[Example 100](#example-100)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%20%20foo%0A--- "open in interactive dingus") ```example foo --- ``` 
foo
[Example 101](#example-101)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%20foo%0A----- "open in interactive dingus") ```example > foo ----- ```

foo

If you want a heading with `> foo` as its literal text, you can use backslash escapes: [Example 102](#example-102)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5C%3E%20foo%0A------ "open in interactive dingus") ```example \> foo ------ ```

> foo

**Compatibility note:** Most existing Markdown implementations do not allow the text of setext headings to span multiple lines. But there is no consensus about how to interpret ```markdown Foo bar --- baz ``` One can find four different interpretations: 1. paragraph "Foo", heading "bar", paragraph "baz" 2. paragraph "Foo bar", thematic break, paragraph "baz" 3. paragraph "Foo bar --- baz" 4. heading "Foo bar", paragraph "baz" We find interpretation 4 most natural, and interpretation 4 increases the expressive power of CommonMark, by allowing multiline headings. Authors who want interpretation 1 can put a blank line after the first paragraph: [Example 103](#example-103)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=Foo%0A%0Abar%0A---%0Abaz "open in interactive dingus") ```example Foo bar --- baz ```

Foo

bar

baz

Authors who want interpretation 2 can put blank lines around the thematic break, [Example 104](#example-104)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=Foo%0Abar%0A%0A---%0A%0Abaz "open in interactive dingus") ```example Foo bar --- baz ```

Foo bar

baz

or use a thematic break that cannot count as a [setext heading underline](#setext-heading-underline), such as [Example 105](#example-105)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=Foo%0Abar%0A*%20*%20*%0Abaz "open in interactive dingus") ```example Foo bar * * * baz ```

Foo bar

baz

Authors who want interpretation 3 can use backslash escapes: [Example 106](#example-106)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=Foo%0Abar%0A%5C---%0Abaz "open in interactive dingus") ```example Foo bar \--- baz ```

Foo bar --- baz

## Indented code blocks[](#indented-code-blocks) An [indented code block](#indented-code-block) is composed of one or more [indented chunks](#indented-chunk) separated by blank lines. An [indented chunk](#indented-chunk) is a sequence of non-blank lines, each preceded by four or more spaces of indentation. The contents of the code block are the literal contents of the lines, including trailing [line endings](#line-ending), minus four spaces of indentation. An indented code block has no [info string](#info-string). An indented code block cannot interrupt a paragraph, so there must be a blank line between a paragraph and a following indented code block. (A blank line is not needed, however, between a code block and a following paragraph.) [Example 107](#example-107)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%20%20a%20simple%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20indented%20code%20block "open in interactive dingus") ```example a simple indented code block ``` 
a simple
      indented code block
If there is any ambiguity between an interpretation of indentation as a code block and as indicating that material belongs to a [list item](#list-items), the list item interpretation takes precedence: [Example 108](#example-108)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20-%20foo%0A%0A%20%20%20%20bar "open in interactive dingus") ```example - foo bar ```

  • foo

    bar

[Example 109](#example-109)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=1.%20%20foo%0A%0A%20%20%20%20-%20bar "open in interactive dingus") ```example 1. foo - bar ```

  1. foo

    • bar
The contents of a code block are literal text, and do not get parsed as Markdown: [Example 110](#example-110)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%20%20%3Ca%2F%3E%0A%20%20%20%20*hi*%0A%0A%20%20%20%20-%20one "open in interactive dingus") ```example *hi* - one ``` 
<a/>
    *hi*

    - one
Here we have three chunks separated by blank lines: [Example 111](#example-111)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%20%20chunk1%0A%0A%20%20%20%20chunk2%0A%20%20%0A%20%0A%20%0A%20%20%20%20chunk3 "open in interactive dingus") ```example chunk1 chunk2 chunk3 ``` 
chunk1

    chunk2



    chunk3
Any initial spaces or tabs beyond four spaces of indentation will be included in the content, even in interior blank lines: [Example 112](#example-112)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%20%20chunk1%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20chunk2 "open in interactive dingus") ```example chunk1 chunk2 ``` 
chunk1
      
      chunk2
An indented code block cannot interrupt a paragraph. (This allows hanging indents and the like.) [Example 113](#example-113)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=Foo%0A%20%20%20%20bar%0A "open in interactive dingus") ```example Foo bar ```

Foo bar

However, any non-blank line with fewer than four spaces of indentation ends the code block immediately. So a paragraph may occur immediately after indented code: [Example 114](#example-114)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%20%20foo%0Abar "open in interactive dingus") ```example foo bar ``` 
foo

And indented code can occur immediately before and after other kinds of blocks: [Example 115](#example-115)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%23%20Heading%0A%20%20%20%20foo%0AHeading%0A------%0A%20%20%20%20foo%0A---- "open in interactive dingus") ```example # Heading foo Heading ------ foo ---- ```

Heading

foo

Heading

The first line can be preceded by more than four spaces of indentation: [Example 116](#example-116)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20foo%0A%20%20%20%20bar "open in interactive dingus") ```example foo bar ``` 
    foo
    bar
Blank lines preceding or following an indented code block are not included in it: [Example 117](#example-117)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%0A%20%20%20%20%0A%20%20%20%20foo%0A%20%20%20%20%0A "open in interactive dingus") ```example foo ``` 
foo
Trailing spaces or tabs are included in the code block's content: [Example 118](#example-118)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%20%20foo%20%20 "open in interactive dingus") ```example foo ```

## Fenced code blocks[](#fenced-code-blocks) A [code fence](#code-fence) is a sequence of at least three consecutive backtick characters (`` ` ``) or tildes (`~`). (Tildes and backticks cannot be mixed.) A [fenced code block](#fenced-code-block) begins with a code fence, preceded by up to three spaces of indentation. The line with the opening code fence may optionally contain some text following the code fence; this is trimmed of leading and trailing spaces or tabs and called the [info string](#info-string). If the [info string](#info-string) comes after a backtick fence, it may not contain any backtick characters. (The reason for this restriction is that otherwise some inline code would be incorrectly interpreted as the beginning of a fenced code block.) The content of the code block consists of all subsequent lines, until a closing [code fence](#code-fence) of the same type as the code block began with (backticks or tildes), and with at least as many backticks or tildes as the opening code fence. If the leading code fence is preceded by N spaces of indentation, then up to N spaces of indentation are removed from each line of the content (if present). (If a content line is not indented, it is preserved unchanged. If it is indented N spaces or less, all of the indentation is removed.) The closing code fence may be preceded by up to three spaces of indentation, and may be followed only by spaces or tabs, which are ignored. If the end of the containing block (or document) is reached and no closing code fence has been found, the code block contains all of the lines after the opening code fence until the end of the containing block (or document). (An alternative spec would require backtracking in the event that a closing code fence is not found. But this makes parsing much less efficient, and there seems to be no real downside to the behavior described here.) A fenced code block may interrupt a paragraph, and does not require a blank line either before or after. The content of a code fence is treated as literal text, not parsed as inlines. The first word of the [info string](#info-string) is typically used to specify the language of the code sample, and rendered in the `class` attribute of the `code` tag. However, this spec does not mandate any particular treatment of the [info string](#info-string). Here is a simple example with backticks: [Example 119](#example-119)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%60%60%60%0A%3C%0A%20%3E%0A%60%60%60 "open in interactive dingus") ````example ``` < > ``` ```` 
<
     >
With tildes: [Example 120](#example-120)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=~~~%0A%3C%0A%20%3E%0A~~~ "open in interactive dingus") ```example ~~~ < > ~~~ ``` 
<
     >
Fewer than three backticks is not enough: [Example 121](#example-121)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%60%60%0Afoo%0A%60%60 "open in interactive dingus") ```example `` foo `` ```

foo

The closing code fence must use the same character as the opening fence: [Example 122](#example-122)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%60%60%60%0Aaaa%0A~~~%0A%60%60%60 "open in interactive dingus") ````example ``` aaa ~~~ ``` ````

## HTML blocks[](#html-blocks) An [HTML block](#html-block) is a group of lines that is treated as raw HTML (and will not be escaped in HTML output). There are seven kinds of [HTML block](#html-block), which can be defined by their start and end conditions. The block begins with a line that meets a [start condition](#start-condition) (after up to three optional spaces of indentation). It ends with the first subsequent line that meets a matching [end condition](#end-condition), or the last line of the document, or the last line of the [container block](#container-blocks) containing the current HTML block, if no line is encountered that meets the [end condition](#end-condition). If the first line meets both the [start condition](#start-condition) and the [end condition](#end-condition), the block will contain just that line. 1. **Start condition:** line begins with the string ``, or the end of the line.\ **End condition:** line contains an end tag ``, ``, ``, or `` (case-insensitive; it need not match the start tag). 2. **Start condition:** line begins with the string ``. 3. **Start condition:** line begins with the string ``. 4. **Start condition:** line begins with the string ``. 5. **Start condition:** line begins with the string ``. 6. **Start condition:** line begins with the string `<` or ``, or the string `/>`.\ **End condition:** line is followed by a [blank line](#blank-line). 7. **Start condition:** line begins with a complete [open tag](#open-tag) (with any [tag name](#tag-name) other than `pre`, `script`, `style`, or `textarea`) or a complete [closing tag](#closing-tag), followed by zero or more spaces and tabs, followed by the end of the line.\ **End condition:** line is followed by a [blank line](#blank-line). HTML blocks continue until they are closed by their appropriate [end condition](#end-condition), or the last line of the document or other [container block](#container-blocks). This means any HTML **within an HTML block** that might otherwise be recognised as a start condition will be ignored by the parser and passed through as-is, without changing the parser's state. For instance, `
` within an HTML block started by `` will not affect the parser state; as the HTML block was started in by start condition 6, it will end at any blank line. This can be surprising:

[Example 148](#example-148)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3Ctable%3E%3Ctr%3E%3Ctd%3E%0A%3Cpre%3E%0A**Hello**%2C%0A%0A_world_.%0A%3C%2Fpre%3E%0A%3C%2Ftd%3E%3C%2Ftr%3E%3C%2Ftable%3E "open in interactive dingus")

```example



**Hello**,

_world_.




```

    

    
    **Hello**,
    
world.
    

    


In this case, the HTML block is terminated by the blank line — the `**Hello**` text remains verbatim — and regular parsing resumes, with a paragraph, emphasised `world` and inline and block HTML following.

All types of [HTML blocks](#html-block) except type 7 may interrupt a paragraph. Blocks of type 7 may not interrupt a paragraph. (This restriction is intended to prevent unwanted interpretation of long tags inside a wrapped paragraph as starting HTML blocks.)

These rules are designed to allow us to work with tags that can function as either block-level or inline-level tags. The `` tag is a nice example. We can surround content with `` tags in three different ways. In this case, we get a raw HTML block, because the `` tag is on a line by itself:

[Example 166](#example-166)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3Cdel%3E%0A*foo*%0A%3C%2Fdel%3E "open in interactive dingus")

*foo*

In this case, we get a raw HTML block that just includes the `` tag (because it ends with the following blank line). So the contents get interpreted as CommonMark:

[Example 167](#example-167)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3Cdel%3E%0A%0A*foo*%0A%0A%3C%2Fdel%3E "open in interactive dingus")

foo

[Example 168](#example-168)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3Cdel%3E*foo*%3C%2Fdel%3E "open in interactive dingus")

This rule differs from John Gruber's original Markdown syntax specification, which says:

> The only restrictions are that block-level HTML elements — e.g. `
`, ``, `
`, `
`, etc. — must be separated from surrounding content by blank lines, and the start and end tags of the block should not be indented with spaces or tabs.

In some ways Gruber's rule is more restrictive than the one given here:

*   It requires that an HTML block be preceded by a blank line.
*   It does not allow the start tag to be indented.
*   It requires a matching end tag, which it also does not allow to be indented.

Most Markdown implementations (including some of Gruber's own) do not respect all of these restrictions.

There is one respect, however, in which Gruber's rule is more liberal than the one given here, since it allows blank lines to occur inside an HTML block. There are two reasons for disallowing them here. First, it removes the need to parse balanced tags, which is expensive and can require backtracking from the end of the document if no matching end tag is found. Second, it provides a very simple and flexible way of including Markdown content inside HTML tags: simply separate the Markdown from the HTML using blank lines:

Compare:

[Example 188](#example-188)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3Cdiv%3E%0A%0A*Emphasized*%20text.%0A%0A%3C%2Fdiv%3E "open in interactive dingus")

```example



*Emphasized* text.



```

    

    
Emphasized text.

    


[Example 189](#example-189)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3Cdiv%3E%0A*Emphasized*%20text.%0A%3C%2Fdiv%3E "open in interactive dingus")

```example


*Emphasized* text.


```

    

    *Emphasized* text.
    


Some Markdown implementations have adopted a convention of interpreting content inside tags as text if the open tag has the attribute `markdown=1`. The rule given above seems a simpler and more elegant way of achieving the same expressive power, which is also much simpler to parse.

The main potential drawback is that one can no longer paste HTML blocks into Markdown documents with 100% reliability. However, *in most cases* this will work fine, because the blank lines in HTML are usually followed by HTML block tags. For example:

[Example 190](#example-190)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3Ctable%3E%0A%0A%3Ctr%3E%0A%0A%3Ctd%3E%0AHi%0A%3C%2Ftd%3E%0A%0A%3C%2Ftr%3E%0A%0A%3C%2Ftable%3E "open in interactive dingus")

```example







Hi







```

    

    

    
    Hi
    
    

    


There are problems, however, if the inner tags are indented *and* separated by spaces, as then they will be interpreted as an indented code block:

[Example 191](#example-191)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3Ctable%3E%0A%0A%20%20%3Ctr%3E%0A%0A%20%20%20%20%3Ctd%3E%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20Hi%0A%20%20%20%20%3C%2Ftd%3E%0A%0A%20%20%3C%2Ftr%3E%0A%0A%3C%2Ftable%3E "open in interactive dingus")

```example



  


    
      Hi
    

  




```

    
<td>
      Hi
    </td>
    

      

    
      

    


Fortunately, blank lines are usually not necessary and can be deleted. The exception is inside `
` tags, but as described [above](#html-block), raw HTML blocks starting with `
` *can* contain blank lines.

## Link reference definitions[](#link-reference-definitions)

A [link reference definition](#link-reference-definition) consists of a [link label](#link-label), optionally preceded by up to three spaces of indentation, followed by a colon (`:`), optional spaces or tabs (including up to one [line ending](#line-ending)), a [link destination](#link-destination), optional spaces or tabs (including up to one [line ending](#line-ending)), and an optional [link title](#link-title), which if it is present must be separated from the [link destination](#link-destination) by spaces or tabs. No further character may occur.

A [link reference definition](#link-reference-definition) does not correspond to a structural element of a document. Instead, it defines a label which can be used in [reference links](#reference-link) and reference-style [images](#images) elsewhere in the document. [Link reference definitions](#link-reference-definition) can come either before or after the links that use them.

[Example 192](#example-192)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5Bfoo%5D%3A%20%2Furl%20%22title%22%0A%0A%5Bfoo%5D "open in interactive dingus")

```example
[foo]: /url "title"

[foo]
```

    
foo


[Example 193](#example-193)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%20%5Bfoo%5D%3A%20%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%2Furl%20%20%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20'the%20title'%20%20%0A%0A%5Bfoo%5D "open in interactive dingus")

```example
   [foo]: 
      /url  
           'the title'  

[foo]
```

    
foo


[Example 194](#example-194)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5BFoo*bar%5C%5D%5D%3Amy_\(url\)%20'title%20\(with%20parens\)'%0A%0A%5BFoo*bar%5C%5D%5D "open in interactive dingus")

```example
[Foo*bar\]]:my_(url) 'title (with parens)'

[Foo*bar\]]
```

    
Foo*bar]


[Example 195](#example-195)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5BFoo%20bar%5D%3A%0A%3Cmy%20url%3E%0A'title'%0A%0A%5BFoo%20bar%5D "open in interactive dingus")

```example
[Foo bar]:

'title'

[Foo bar]
```

    
Foo bar


The title may extend over multiple lines:

[Example 196](#example-196)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5Bfoo%5D%3A%20%2Furl%20'%0Atitle%0Aline1%0Aline2%0A'%0A%0A%5Bfoo%5D "open in interactive dingus")

```example
[foo]: /url '
title
line1
line2
'

[foo]
```

    
foo


However, it may not contain a [blank line](#blank-line):

[Example 197](#example-197)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5Bfoo%5D%3A%20%2Furl%20'title%0A%0Awith%20blank%20line'%0A%0A%5Bfoo%5D "open in interactive dingus")

```example
[foo]: /url 'title

with blank line'

[foo]
```

    
[foo]: /url 'title

    
with blank line'

    
[foo]


The title may be omitted:

[Example 198](#example-198)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5Bfoo%5D%3A%0A%2Furl%0A%0A%5Bfoo%5D "open in interactive dingus")

```example
[foo]:
/url

[foo]
```

    
foo


The link destination may not be omitted:

[Example 199](#example-199)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5Bfoo%5D%3A%0A%0A%5Bfoo%5D "open in interactive dingus")

```example
[foo]:

[foo]
```

    
[foo]:

    
[foo]


However, an empty link destination may be specified using angle brackets:

[Example 200](#example-200)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5Bfoo%5D%3A%20%3C%3E%0A%0A%5Bfoo%5D "open in interactive dingus")

```example
[foo]: <>

[foo]
```

    
foo


The title must be separated from the link destination by spaces or tabs:

[Example 201](#example-201)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5Bfoo%5D%3A%20%3Cbar%3E\(baz\)%0A%0A%5Bfoo%5D "open in interactive dingus")

```example
[foo]: (baz)

[foo]
```

    
[foo]: (baz)

    
[foo]


Both title and destination can contain backslash escapes and literal backslashes:

[Example 202](#example-202)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5Bfoo%5D%3A%20%2Furl%5Cbar%5C*baz%20%22foo%5C%22bar%5Cbaz%22%0A%0A%5Bfoo%5D "open in interactive dingus")

```example
[foo]: /url\bar\*baz "foo\"bar\baz"

[foo]
```

    
foo


A link can come before its corresponding definition:

[Example 203](#example-203)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5Bfoo%5D%0A%0A%5Bfoo%5D%3A%20url "open in interactive dingus")

```example
[foo]

[foo]: url
```

    
foo


If there are several matching definitions, the first one takes precedence:

[Example 204](#example-204)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5Bfoo%5D%0A%0A%5Bfoo%5D%3A%20first%0A%5Bfoo%5D%3A%20second "open in interactive dingus")

```example
[foo]

[foo]: first
[foo]: second
```

    
foo


As noted in the section on [Links](#links), matching of labels is case-insensitive (see [matches](#matches)).

[Example 205](#example-205)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5BFOO%5D%3A%20%2Furl%0A%0A%5BFoo%5D "open in interactive dingus")

```example
[FOO]: /url

[Foo]
```

    
Foo


[Example 206](#example-206)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5B%CE%91%CE%93%CE%A9%5D%3A%20%2F%CF%86%CE%BF%CF%85%0A%0A%5B%CE%B1%CE%B3%CF%89%5D "open in interactive dingus")

```example
[ΑΓΩ]: /φου

[αγω]
```

    
αγω


Whether something is a [link reference definition](#link-reference-definition) is independent of whether the link reference it defines is used in the document. Thus, for example, the following document contains just a link reference definition, and no visible content:

[Example 207](#example-207)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5Bfoo%5D%3A%20%2Furl "open in interactive dingus")

```example
[foo]: /url
```

```
```

Here is another one:

[Example 208](#example-208)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5B%0Afoo%0A%5D%3A%20%2Furl%0Abar "open in interactive dingus")

```example
[
foo
]: /url
bar
```

    
bar


This is not a link reference definition, because there are characters other than spaces or tabs after the title:

[Example 209](#example-209)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5Bfoo%5D%3A%20%2Furl%20%22title%22%20ok "open in interactive dingus")

```example
[foo]: /url "title" ok
```

    
[foo]: /url "title" ok


This is a link reference definition, but it has no title:

[Example 210](#example-210)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5Bfoo%5D%3A%20%2Furl%0A%22title%22%20ok "open in interactive dingus")

```example
[foo]: /url
"title" ok
```

    
"title" ok


This is not a link reference definition, because it is indented four spaces:

[Example 211](#example-211)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%20%20%5Bfoo%5D%3A%20%2Furl%20%22title%22%0A%0A%5Bfoo%5D "open in interactive dingus")

```example
    [foo]: /url "title"

[foo]
```

    
[foo]: /url "title"
    

    
[foo]


This is not a link reference definition, because it occurs inside a code block:

[Example 212](#example-212)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%60%60%60%0A%5Bfoo%5D%3A%20%2Furl%0A%60%60%60%0A%0A%5Bfoo%5D "open in interactive dingus")

````example
```
[foo]: /url
```

[foo]
````

    
[foo]: /url
    

    
[foo]


A [link reference definition](#link-reference-definition) cannot interrupt a paragraph.

[Example 213](#example-213)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=Foo%0A%5Bbar%5D%3A%20%2Fbaz%0A%0A%5Bbar%5D "open in interactive dingus")

```example
Foo
[bar]: /baz

[bar]
```

    
Foo
    [bar]: /baz

    
[bar]


However, it can directly follow other block elements, such as headings and thematic breaks, and it need not be followed by a blank line.

[Example 214](#example-214)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%23%20%5BFoo%5D%0A%5Bfoo%5D%3A%20%2Furl%0A%3E%20bar "open in interactive dingus")

```example
# [Foo]
[foo]: /url
> bar
```

    
Foo

    

    
bar

    


[Example 215](#example-215)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5Bfoo%5D%3A%20%2Furl%0Abar%0A%3D%3D%3D%0A%5Bfoo%5D "open in interactive dingus")

```example
[foo]: /url
bar
===
[foo]
```

    
bar

    
foo


[Example 216](#example-216)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5Bfoo%5D%3A%20%2Furl%0A%3D%3D%3D%0A%5Bfoo%5D "open in interactive dingus")

```example
[foo]: /url
===
[foo]
```

    
===
    foo


Several [link reference definitions](#link-reference-definition) can occur one after another, without intervening blank lines.

[Example 217](#example-217)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5Bfoo%5D%3A%20%2Ffoo-url%20%22foo%22%0A%5Bbar%5D%3A%20%2Fbar-url%0A%20%20%22bar%22%0A%5Bbaz%5D%3A%20%2Fbaz-url%0A%0A%5Bfoo%5D%2C%0A%5Bbar%5D%2C%0A%5Bbaz%5D "open in interactive dingus")

```example
[foo]: /foo-url "foo"
[bar]: /bar-url
  "bar"
[baz]: /baz-url

[foo],
[bar],
[baz]
```

    
foo,
    bar,
    baz


[Link reference definitions](#link-reference-definition) can occur inside block containers, like lists and block quotations. They affect the entire document, not just the container in which they are defined:

[Example 218](#example-218)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%5Bfoo%5D%0A%0A%3E%20%5Bfoo%5D%3A%20%2Furl "open in interactive dingus")

```example
[foo]

> [foo]: /url
```

    
foo

    

    


## Paragraphs[](#paragraphs)

A sequence of non-blank lines that cannot be interpreted as other kinds of blocks forms a [paragraph](#paragraph). The contents of the paragraph are the result of parsing the paragraph's raw content as inlines. The paragraph's raw content is formed by concatenating the lines and removing initial and final spaces or tabs.

A simple example with two paragraphs:

[Example 219](#example-219)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=aaa%0A%0Abbb "open in interactive dingus")

```example
aaa

bbb
```

    
aaa

    
bbb


Paragraphs can contain multiple lines, but no blank lines:

[Example 220](#example-220)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=aaa%0Abbb%0A%0Accc%0Addd "open in interactive dingus")

```example
aaa
bbb

ccc
ddd
```

    
aaa
    bbb

    
ccc
    ddd


Multiple blank lines between paragraphs have no effect:

[Example 221](#example-221)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=aaa%0A%0A%0Abbb "open in interactive dingus")

```example
aaa


bbb
```

    
aaa

    
bbb


Leading spaces or tabs are skipped:

[Example 222](#example-222)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20aaa%0A%20bbb "open in interactive dingus")

```example
  aaa
 bbb
```

    
aaa
    bbb


Lines after the first may be indented any amount, since indented code blocks cannot interrupt paragraphs.

[Example 223](#example-223)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=aaa%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20bbb%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20ccc "open in interactive dingus")

```example
aaa
             bbb
                                       ccc
```

    
aaa
    bbb
    ccc


However, the first line may be preceded by up to three spaces of indentation. Four spaces of indentation is too many:

[Example 224](#example-224)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%20aaa%0Abbb "open in interactive dingus")

```example
   aaa
bbb
```

    
aaa
    bbb


[Example 225](#example-225)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%20%20aaa%0Abbb "open in interactive dingus")

```example
    aaa
bbb
```

    
aaa
    

    
bbb


Final spaces or tabs are stripped before inline parsing, so a paragraph that ends with two or more spaces will not end with a [hard line break](#hard-line-break):

[Example 226](#example-226)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=aaa%20%20%20%20%20%0Abbb%20%20%20%20%20 "open in interactive dingus")

```example
aaa     
bbb     
```

    
aaa

    bbb


## Blank lines[](#blank-lines)

[Blank lines](#blank-lines) between block-level elements are ignored, except for the role they play in determining whether a [list](#list) is [tight](#tight) or [loose](#loose).

Blank lines at the beginning and end of the document are also ignored.

[Example 227](#example-227)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%0A%0Aaaa%0A%20%20%0A%0A%23%20aaa%0A%0A%20%20 "open in interactive dingus")

```example
  

aaa
  

# aaa

  
```

    
aaa

    
aaa


# Container blocks[](#container-blocks)

A [container block](#container-blocks) is a block that has other blocks as its contents. There are two basic kinds of container blocks: [block quotes](#block-quotes) and [list items](#list-items). [Lists](#list) are meta-containers for [list items](#list-items).

We define the syntax for container blocks recursively. The general form of the definition is:

> If X is a sequence of blocks, then the result of transforming X in such-and-such a way is a container of type Y with these blocks as its content.

So, we explain what counts as a block quote or list item by explaining how these can be *generated* from their contents. This should suffice to define the syntax, although it does not give a recipe for *parsing* these constructions. (A recipe is provided below in the section entitled [A parsing strategy](#appendix-a-parsing-strategy).)

## Block quotes[](#block-quotes)

A [block quote marker](#block-quote-marker), optionally preceded by up to three spaces of indentation, consists of (a) the character `>` together with a following space of indentation, or (b) a single character `>` not followed by a space of indentation.

The following rules define [block quotes](#block-quotes):

1.  **Basic case.** If a string of lines *Ls* constitute a sequence of blocks *Bs*, then the result of prepending a [block quote marker](#block-quote-marker) to the beginning of each line in *Ls* is a [block quote](#block-quotes) containing *Bs*.

2.  **Laziness.** If a string of lines *Ls* constitute a [block quote](#block-quotes) with contents *Bs*, then the result of deleting the initial [block quote marker](#block-quote-marker) from one or more lines in which the next character other than a space or tab after the [block quote marker](#block-quote-marker) is [paragraph continuation text](#paragraph-continuation-text) is a block quote with *Bs* as its content. [Paragraph continuation text](#paragraph-continuation-text) is text that will be parsed as part of the content of a paragraph, but does not occur at the beginning of the paragraph.

3.  **Consecutiveness.** A document cannot contain two [block quotes](#block-quotes) in a row unless there is a [blank line](#blank-line) between them.

Nothing else counts as a [block quote](#block-quotes).

Here is a simple example:

[Example 228](#example-228)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%20%23%20Foo%0A%3E%20bar%0A%3E%20baz "open in interactive dingus")

```example
> # Foo
> bar
> baz
```

    

    
Foo

    
bar
    baz

    


The space or tab after the `>` characters can be omitted:

[Example 229](#example-229)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%23%20Foo%0A%3Ebar%0A%3E%20baz "open in interactive dingus")

```example
># Foo
>bar
> baz
```

    

    
Foo

    
bar
    baz

    


The `>` characters can be preceded by up to three spaces of indentation:

[Example 230](#example-230)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%20%3E%20%23%20Foo%0A%20%20%20%3E%20bar%0A%20%3E%20baz "open in interactive dingus")

```example
   > # Foo
   > bar
 > baz
```

    

    
Foo

    
bar
    baz

    


Four spaces of indentation is too many:

[Example 231](#example-231)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%20%20%20%20%3E%20%23%20Foo%0A%20%20%20%20%3E%20bar%0A%20%20%20%20%3E%20baz "open in interactive dingus")

```example
    > # Foo
    > bar
    > baz
```

    
> # Foo
    > bar
    > baz
    


The Laziness clause allows us to omit the `>` before [paragraph continuation text](#paragraph-continuation-text):

[Example 232](#example-232)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%20%23%20Foo%0A%3E%20bar%0Abaz "open in interactive dingus")

```example
> # Foo
> bar
baz
```

    

    
Foo

    
bar
    baz

    


A block quote can contain some lazy and some non-lazy continuation lines:

[Example 233](#example-233)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%20bar%0Abaz%0A%3E%20foo "open in interactive dingus")

```example
> bar
baz
> foo
```

    

    
bar
    baz
    foo

    


Laziness only applies to lines that would have been continuations of paragraphs had they been prepended with [block quote markers](#block-quote-marker). For example, the `> `cannot be omitted in the second line of

```markdown
> foo
> ---
```

without changing the meaning:

[Example 234](#example-234)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%20foo%0A--- "open in interactive dingus")

```example
> foo
---
```

    

    
foo

    

    


Similarly, if we omit the `> `in the second line of

```markdown
> - foo
> - bar
```

then the block quote ends after the first line:

[Example 235](#example-235)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%20-%20foo%0A-%20bar "open in interactive dingus")

```example
> - foo
- bar
```

    

    
    
    
  • foo
    • 
    

    

    
    
    
  • bar
    • 
    


For the same reason, we can't omit the `> `in front of subsequent lines of an indented or fenced code block:

[Example 236](#example-236)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%20%20%20%20%20foo%0A%20%20%20%20bar "open in interactive dingus")

```example
>     foo
    bar
```

    

    
foo
    

    

    
bar
    


[Example 237](#example-237)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%20%60%60%60%0Afoo%0A%60%60%60 "open in interactive dingus")

````example
> ```
foo
```
````

    

    

    

    
foo

    


Note that in the following case, we have a [lazy continuation line](#lazy-continuation-line):

[Example 238](#example-238)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%20foo%0A%20%20%20%20-%20bar "open in interactive dingus")

```example
> foo
    - bar
```

    

    
foo
    - bar

    


To see why, note that in

```markdown
> foo
>     - bar
```

the `- bar` is indented too far to start a list, and can't be an indented code block because indented code blocks cannot interrupt paragraphs, so it is [paragraph continuation text](#paragraph-continuation-text).

A block quote can be empty:

[Example 239](#example-239)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E "open in interactive dingus")

```example
>
```

    

    


[Example 240](#example-240)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%0A%3E%20%20%0A%3E%20 "open in interactive dingus")

```example
>
>  
> 
```

    

    


A block quote can have initial or final blank lines:

[Example 241](#example-241)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%0A%3E%20foo%0A%3E%20%20 "open in interactive dingus")

```example
>
> foo
>  
```

    

    
foo

    


A blank line always separates block quotes:

[Example 242](#example-242)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%20foo%0A%0A%3E%20bar "open in interactive dingus")

```example
> foo

> bar
```

    

    
foo

    

    

    
bar

    


(Most current Markdown implementations, including John Gruber's original `Markdown.pl`, will parse this example as a single block quote with two paragraphs. But it seems better to allow the author to decide whether two block quotes or one are wanted.)

Consecutiveness means that if we put these block quotes together, we get a single block quote:

[Example 243](#example-243)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%20foo%0A%3E%20bar "open in interactive dingus")

```example
> foo
> bar
```

    

    
foo
    bar

    


To get a block quote with two paragraphs, use:

[Example 244](#example-244)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%20foo%0A%3E%0A%3E%20bar "open in interactive dingus")

```example
> foo
>
> bar
```

    

    
foo

    
bar

    


Block quotes can interrupt paragraphs:

[Example 245](#example-245)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=foo%0A%3E%20bar "open in interactive dingus")

```example
foo
> bar
```

    
foo

    

    
bar

    


In general, blank lines are not needed before or after block quotes:

[Example 246](#example-246)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%20aaa%0A***%0A%3E%20bbb "open in interactive dingus")

```example
> aaa
***
> bbb
```

    

    
aaa

    

    

    

    
bbb

    


However, because of laziness, a blank line is needed between a block quote and a following paragraph:

[Example 247](#example-247)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%20bar%0Abaz "open in interactive dingus")

```example
> bar
baz
```

    

    
bar
    baz

    


[Example 248](#example-248)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%20bar%0A%0Abaz "open in interactive dingus")

```example
> bar

baz
```

    

    
bar

    

    
baz


[Example 249](#example-249)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%20bar%0A%3E%0Abaz "open in interactive dingus")

```example
> bar
>
baz
```

    

    
bar

    

    
baz


It is a consequence of the Laziness rule that any number of initial `>`s may be omitted on a continuation line of a nested block quote:

[Example 250](#example-250)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%20%3E%20%3E%20foo%0Abar "open in interactive dingus")

```example
> > > foo
bar
```

    

    

    

    
foo
    bar

    

    

    


[Example 251](#example-251)[Try It](/commonmark-spec-viewer/dingus?text=%3E%3E%3E%20foo%0A%3E%20bar%0A%3E%3Ebaz "open in interactive dingus")

```example
>>> foo
> bar
>>baz

foo
